1.1 Plot Structure

        Completion requirements
        



If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 1, you can open it in Google Docs. Use the study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too.

Greetings from Silicon Valley High School!  Welcome to English 9.  This course is designed to make you a proficient reader, writer, and thinker at the high school level.  We begin with the short story...
The Short Story
The modern short story is a descendant of ancient Greek mythology and those Brothers Grimm fairy tales passed orally from generation to generation: stories best told at night around a fire, whose purposes were to create a sense of amazement.  As
    such, the modern short story took on Gothic elements: themes of bloody revenge, bitter ironies, and disturbing endings.  Instead of heroes and gods being the focus, however, most short fiction champions the common character, especially voices
    of the "loner," "loser," or "outcast"--those on the outside or fringes of society.
The "Father of the American short story," Edgar Allan Poe, formalized the short fiction genre at the end of the Romantic Period and the beginning of the Victorian Era, a time when the United States was engaged in bloody expansion (against Mexico), genocide
    (against Native Americans), and slavery (on Southern plantations). Poe's tales mirrored the violence in America, the beauty of Romantic language, and the simplicity of Realism's prose.  For Poe, the purpose of the short story was to return to
    that ancient oral culture: to catch lightning in a bottle in one reading.
Unlike longer works, short fiction delivers a knockout punch.  Short stories compress time by colliding all narrative elements at high speed: plot (narrative conflict), setting (time and place), characterization (protagonists against antagonists), point of view (narrator's perspective), and theme (author's message).
